title: Metrics That Hurt (in a Good Way)
hook: If your metrics don’t change behavior, they are decorative. Modern AMS uses indicators that expose waste, risk, and fake progress.
idea: Most AMS dashboards look healthy while the system is sick. The fix is not more KPIs, but fewer metrics that force decisions.
principles: Expose repetition and delay — that’s where money leaks.
Tie every metric to an action: if it goes red, someone knows exactly what to do.

flow.name: Time to First Real Signal
flow.meaning: How fast we move from noise to a concrete hypothesis.
flow.why_it_matters: Slow diagnosis is more expensive than slow fixing.

flow.name: End-to-End Resolution Time
flow.meaning: From first report to verified business recovery.
flow.why_it_matters: Users don’t care when IT 'started working', only when it works again.

stability.name: Repeat Incident Rate
stability.meaning: Same symptom, same root cause within 30/60 days.
stability.why_it_matters: This is deferred cost pretending to be support.

stability.name: Change-Induced Incidents
stability.why_it_matters: Shows quality of testing and risk assessment.

economics.name: Cost per Solved Business Impact
economics.meaning: Effort spent per issue that actually blocked a process.
economics.why_it_matters: Separates real work from ticket noise.

economics.name: Top 10 Demand Drivers
economics.meaning: The small set of causes generating most of the load.
economics.why_it_matters: This is where automation and prevention pay back.

decision_triggers.action: Freeze new cosmetic changes, open Problem backlog with owners and deadlines.
Tighten entry criteria: mandatory test evidence and blast-radius declaration.
Analyze diagnosis delays, missing data, and handoff friction.

copilot_moves: Cluster tickets by symptom, not by short description.
Detect hidden repeats even when wording is different.
Auto-generate weekly insight: what got worse, why, and what to stop doing.
outputs: Suggested prevention candidates with estimated load reduction

why_it_makes_support_better_and_cheaper: Teams stop gaming SLA and start killing root causes.
Management sees where money is burned silently.
Automation targets become obvious instead of ideological.
anti_patterns_to_kill: Green SLA dashboards with angry users
Dozens of KPIs nobody acts on
weekly_review_questions: What repeated this week that should not have existed?
Which metric moved — and what decision did we take because of it?
What can we eliminate instead of optimize?
